messages.text:
```julia> v[1] isa eltype(v)
false```
That's... interesting. This is a custom array type with just one non-zero element of type T. I store the element value, index and the vector size only. The thing above happens when calling it with an irrational
`v = MaybeHotVector(π, 2, 33)`
Ok that comes from `zero(Irrational) = false`   which is not an `Irrational`

messages.text:
Hi, I am quite confused by this behavior:
```julia> zeros(Union{Float64, Missing}, 2, 0) .* randn(2)
2×0 Array{Union{Missing, Float64},2}

julia> zeros(Union{Float64, Missing}, 2, 2) .* randn(2)
2×2 Array{Float64,2}:
 -0.0  -0.0
 -0.0  -0.0```
Is there any reason why broadcasting is unstable when similar operations on array like matrix multiplication are?
```julia> randn(2, 2) * zeros(Union{Float64, Missing}, 2, 2)
2×2 Array{Union{Missing, Float64},2}:
 0.0  0.0
 0.0  0.0

julia> randn(2, 2) * zeros(Union{Float64, Missing}, 2, 0)
2×0 Array{Union{Missing, Float64},2}```

elements.text: Hi, I am quite confused by this behavior:

julia> zeros(Union{Float64, Missing}, 2, 0) .* randn(2)
2×0 Array{Union{Missing, Float64},2}

julia> zeros(Union{Float64, Missing}, 2, 2) .* randn(2)
2×2 Array{Float64,2}:
 -0.0  -0.0
 -0.0  -0.0
Is there any reason why broadcasting is unstable when similar operations on array like matrix multiplication are?

julia> randn(2, 2) * zeros(Union{Float64, Missing}, 2, 2)
2×2 Array{Union{Missing, Float64},2}:
 0.0  0.0
 0.0  0.0

julia> randn(2, 2) * zeros(Union{Float64, Missing}, 2, 0)
2×0 Array{Union{Missing, Float64},2}

messages.text:
Can anyone on Windows replicate this? (I get this in GH actions, you might(?) need mingw for `cat`):
```julia> write("foo", "foo")
3

julia> sprint() do io
           run(pipeline(ignorestatus(`cat foo`); stdout=io))
       end
""

julia> sprint() do io
           run(pipeline(ignorestatus(`cat foo`); stdout=io))
       end
"foo"```

messages.text:
Is there a reason why `lock/unlock(::Channel)`  is a thing but not `lock(f, ::Channel)` , while `ReentrantLock` does have that nice second version? If not I'll submit a PR.

I know `@lock` is a thing (works for any type) but it's not exported nor used anywhere, so I figured it shouldn't be used.

messages.text: `@btime` returns the value of an expression whilst printing timing to the REPL,  `@belapsed` returns the time taken (or perhaps the minimum over a bunch of trials), `@benchmark` returns a structure with timing data. But what if I want *both* the value of the expression and also the time taken to evaluate it. Can that be done in a oner?

messages.text:
I used to use that pattern in a few places.
NamedDims.jl used to have `@test_modern` which was short for `if VERSION >= v"1.3"` and then either test or test_broken.

But more and more I am becoming convinced that that pattern is rarely useful. At least on things I do.
 `@test_broken` makes sense if we plan to fix it. Noting that if a `@test_broken` errors if it passes.
Which happed recently that something just started working randomly on 1.0.5 on Linux only.
I think the more useful pattern is just `cond || @test...` , which means I promise this works on e.g. this platform thus version etc. But if the condition isn't met, then I make no promises.

But that's because generally I have a set of systems that are supported which are never `@test_broken` . And everything else, if it doesn't work from getting the systems I care about to work the way I want, then I am not going to come back and fix them later.

In particular though mostly these are tests on maximum number of allocations.

elements.text: what do people think about these macros
are they worth being added to
Test
stdlib?

I used to use that pattern in a few places.
NamedDims.jl used to have
@test_modern
which was short for
if VERSION >= v"1.3"

and then either test or test_broken.

But more and more I am becoming convinced that that pattern is rarely useful. At least on things I do.
@test_broken
makes sense if we plan to fix it. Noting that if a
@test_broken

errors if it passes.
Which happed recently that something just started working randomly on 1.0.5 on Linux only.
I think the more useful pattern is just
cond || @test...

, which means I promise this works on e.g. this platform thus version etc. But if the condition isn't met, then I make no promises.

But that's because generally I have a set of systems that are supported which are never
@test_broken

. And everything else, if it doesn't work from getting the systems I care about to work the way I want, then I am not going to come back and fix them later.

In particular though mostly these are tests on maximum number of allocations.

messages.text: I have been pair programming Julia with a colleague, with Python background using a very TDD oriented approach. But my Julia habits are very REPL oriented in contrast. This does not seems to mesh well. The frequent test running he wants to do, does not seem to mesh well with Julia. This makes me wonder, how does the average Julia developer work? How many do TDD? Who does more REPL style development like me? Or something else? And if you do TDD, then how to you make that work well with Julia?

elements.text: I have been pair programming Julia with a colleague, with Python background using a very TDD oriented approach. But my Julia habits are very REPL oriented in contrast. This does not seems to mesh well. The frequent test running he wants to do, does not seem to mesh well with Julia. This makes me wonder, how does the average Julia developer work? How many do TDD? Who does more REPL style development like me? Or something else? And if you do TDD, then how to you make that work well with Julia?

messages.text:
On testing.
I think it might actually be possible to testing tool in Julia that using some of the same tricks as Revise does to workout which tests need to be re-run based on code getting invalidated by changes.
Doing this (+daemon mode kind of stuff to avoid precompilation/startup) could make for the kind of ultra-fast TDD loops that some of the TDD sub-doctrines like.

elements.text:
On testing.
I think it might actually be possible to testing tool in Julia that using some of the same tricks as Revise does to workout which tests need to be re-run based on code getting invalidated by changes.
Doing this (+daemon mode kind of stuff to avoid precompilation/startup) could make for the kind of ultra-fast TDD loops that some of the TDD sub-doctrines like.

messages.text:
I once asked on discourse about interaction between `map` and `pairs`: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/map-over-namedtuple-keys-and-values-confusing-error/26866/5>. Then the reaction was not really conclusive whether this should work or not.
Now I noticed another similar case where there is even less ambiguity possible: `map(p -> p[1] => p[2], pairs(1:3) |> collect)` gives `[1 => 1, 2 => 2, 3 => 3]` , while `map(p -> p[1] => p[2], pairs(1:3))` results in error *`map is not defined on dictionaries`.*
What do you think: should the second line without collect also work?

attachments.title: Map over namedtuple keys and values: confusing error
attachments.text: Bumping this thread - so there is indeed no way to map or broadcast over pairs(...) (iterable of pairs) without collecting this iterable into an array?
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Map over namedtuple keys and values: confusing error

messages.text: I am using DifferentialEquations with an ODEProblem.  I would then like to drive it with the RobustAdaptiveMetropolisSampler to search parameter space.  Unfortunately, there are many parameter combinations which fail to find a solution with the ODE solver.  Is there a way to get a return value from these failed runs so that I can convert it to a 0 in the cost function?

attachments.title: How to enforce shared behavior for subtype constructors of abstract type
attachments.text: In Makie I have an abstract type Layoutable. Whenever a Layoutable is created with a Figure passed as the parent, I want the layoutable added to the figure’s children. The problem is that this behavior needs to happen in the constructor, which is unique for each struct. So I have no location where I can place a generic function that allows me to hook behavior into every Layoutable subtype. Right now I’m doing this with a macro, so one has to create new Layoutable types via macro and the behavio...

It just becomes annoying when I get thrown down the dependency hell...

messages.text:
Hi! I would like to fix the following in Julia 1.6:
```using Dates
t0 = DateTime(2021, 1, 25, 9)
tend = DateTime(2021, 1, 25, 12)
(t0:tend) .+ Day(1)```
Too late?

elements.text: Hi! I would like to fix the following in Julia 1.6:

using Dates
t0 = DateTime(2021, 1, 25, 9)
tend = DateTime(2021, 1, 25, 12)
(t0:tend) .+ Day(1)
Too late?

messages.text:
<@U69BL50BF>
Really minor problems!
Fixed with <https://github.com/FluxML/Metalhead.jl/pull/75> and <https://github.com/FluxML/Flux.jl/pull/1476>
Bumped the compat of Flux and Colors for Metalhead.jl
Bumped the compat of Adapt for Flux.jl
Metalhead works now!

For the time being(before the above PRs get merged), if anyone wants to install Flux and Metalhead(and are ready to work with Flux 0.12dev), they can just add my repo from the above two PRs:slightly_smiling_face:

messages.text: <https://github.com/google-research/structured-additive-IR>

"An intermediate program representation, based on <http://mlir.llvm.org/|MLIR> and designed to express implementation decisions on a program without losing the high-level structure of the code. It encodes implementation choices as attributes added on to existing operations (hence "additive" in the name)."

Posted in general incase it's relevant to Julia dev. Didn't think it really belonged in random, but happy to move it there if people think so
